title: Spearphishing Attachment
descrption: Spearphishing attachment is a specific variant of spearphishing. Spearphishing attachment is different from other forms of spearphishing in that it employs the use of malware attached to an email. All forms of spearphishing are electronically delivered social engineering targeted at a specific individual, company, or industry. In this scenario, adversaries attach a file to the spearphishing email and usually rely upon User Execution to gain execution.There are many options for the attachment such as Microsoft Office documents, executables, PDFs, or archived files. Upon opening the attachment (and potentially clicking past protections), the adversary's payload exploits a vulnerability or directly executes on the user's system. The text of the spearphishing email usually tries to give a plausible reason why the file should be opened, and may explain how to bypass system protections in order to do so. The email may also contain instructions on how to decrypt an attachment, such as a zip file password, in order to evade email boundary defenses. Adversaries frequently manipulate file extensions and icons in order to make attached executables appear to be document files, or files exploiting one application appear to be a file for a different one.
Data Sources: File monitoring, Packet capture, Network intrusion detection system, Detonation chamber, Email gateway, Mail server

related.Name: admin@338
related.Description: admin@338 has sent emails with malicious Microsoft Office documents attached.[92]

related.Name: APT12
related.Description: APT12 has sent emails with malicious Microsoft Office documents and PDFs attached.[88][89]

related.Name: APT19
related.Description: APT19 sent spearphishing emails with malicious attachments in RTF and XLSM formats to deliver initial exploits.[62]

related.Name: APT28
related.Description: APT28 sent spearphishing emails containing malicious Microsoft Office attachments.[22][23][24][25][26][27]

related.Name: APT29
related.Description: APT29 has used spearphishing emails with an attachment to deliver files with exploits to initial victims.[33][34]

related.Name: APT32
related.Description: APT32 has sent spearphishing emails with a malicious executable disguised as a document or spreadsheet.[74][75][76][77]

related.Name: APT37
related.Description: APT37 delivers malware using spearphishing emails with malicious HWP attachments.[43][44][45]

related.Name: APT39
related.Description: APT39 leveraged spearphishing emails with malicious attachments to initially compromise victims.[78]

related.Name: APT41
related.Description: APT41 sent spearphishing emails with attachments such as compiled HTML (.chm) files to initially compromise their victims.[95]

related.Name: BRONZE BUTLER
related.Description: BRONZE BUTLER used spearphishing emails with malicious Microsoft Word attachments to infect victims.[65]

related.Name: Cobalt Group
related.Description: Cobalt Group has sent spearphishing emails with various attachment types to corporate and personal email accounts of victim organizations. Attachment types have included .rtf, .doc, .xls, archives containing LNK files, and password protected archives containing .exe and .scr executables.[35][36][37][38][39][40][41][42]

related.Name: Darkhotel
related.Description: Darkhotel has sent spearphishing emails with malicious RAR attachments.[73]

related.Name: DarkHydrus
related.Description: DarkHydrus has sent spearphishing emails with password-protected RAR archives containing malicious Excel Web Query files (.iqy). The group has also sent spearphishing emails that contained malicious Microsoft Office documents that use the "attachedTemplate" technique to load a template from a remote server.[19][20][21]

related.Name: Dragonfly 2.0
related.Description: Dragonfly 2.0 used spearphishing with Microsoft Office attachments to target victims.[63][64]

related.Name: Elderwood
related.Description: Elderwood has delivered zero-day exploits and malware to victims via targeted emails containing malicious attachments.[31][32]

related.Name: Emotet
related.Description: Emotet has been delivered by phishing emails containing attachments.[3][4][5][6][7][8][9][10]

related.Name: FIN4
related.Description: FIN4 has used spearphishing emails containing attachments (which are often stolen, legitimate documents sent from compromised accounts) with embedded malicious macros.[66][67]

related.Name: FIN7
related.Description: FIN7 sent spearphishing emails with either malicious Microsoft Documents or RTF files attached.[48][49][50]

related.Name: FIN8
related.Description: FIN8 has distributed targeted emails containing Word documents with embedded malicious macros.[13][14][15]

related.Name: Gallmaker
related.Description: Gallmaker sent emails with malicious Microsoft Office documents attached.[30]

related.Name: Gorgon Group
related.Description: Gorgon Group sent emails to victims with malicious Microsoft Office documents attached.[11]

related.Name: Kimsuky
related.Description: Kimsuky has used emails containing Word, Excel and/or HWP (Hangul Word Processor) documents in their spearphishing campaigns.[90][91]

related.Name: Lazarus Group
related.Description: Lazarus Group has targeted victims with spearphishing emails containing malicious Microsoft Word documents.[28]

related.Name: Leviathan
related.Description: Leviathan has sent spearphishing emails with malicious attachments, including .rtf, .doc, and .xls files.[46]

related.Name: Machete
related.Description: Machete has delivered spearphishing emails that contain a zipped file with malicious contents.[93][94]

related.Name: Magic Hound
related.Description: Magic Hound sent malicious attachments to victims over email, including an Excel spreadsheet containing macros to download Pupy.[47]

related.Name: menuPass
related.Description: menuPass has sent malicious Office documents via email as part of spearphishing campaigns as well as executables disguised as documents.[58][59][60][61]

related.Name: MuddyWater
related.Description: MuddyWater has compromised third parties and used compromised accounts to send spearphishing emails with targeted attachments to recipients.[16][17][18]

related.Name: OceanSalt
related.Description: OceanSalt has been delivered via spearphishing emails with Microsoft Office attachments.[1]

related.Name: OilRig
related.Description: OilRig has sent spearphising emails with malicious attachments to potential victims using compromised and/or spoofed email accounts.[55][56][57]

related.Name: Patchwork
related.Description: Patchwork has used spearphishing with an attachment to deliver files with exploits to initial victims.[51][52][53][54]

related.Name: PLATINUM
related.Description: PLATINUM has sent spearphishing emails with attachments to victims as its primary initial access vector.[69]

related.Name: Rancor
related.Description: Rancor has attached a malicious document to an email to gain initial access.[12]

related.Name: Silence
related.Description: Silence has sent emails with malicious DOCX, CHM and ZIP attachments. [80][81]

related.Name: TA459
related.Description: TA459 has targeted victims using spearphishing emails with malicious Microsoft Word attachments.[29]

related.Name: TA505
related.Description: TA505 has used spearphishing emails with malicious attachments to initially compromise victims.[82][83][84][85][86][87]

related.Name: The White Company
related.Description: The White Company has sent phishing emails with malicious Microsoft Word attachments to victims.[79]

related.Name: TrickBot
related.Description: TrickBot has used an email with an Excel sheet containing a malicious macro to deploy the malware[2]

related.Name: Tropic Trooper
related.Description: Tropic Trooper sent spearphishing emails that contained malicious Microsoft Office attachments.[70][71][72]

related.Name: Turla
related.Description: Turla has used spearphishing emails to deliver BrainTest as a malicious attachment.[68]
Anti-virus can also automatically quarantine suspicious files.
Network intrusion prevention systems and systems designed to scan and remove malicious email attachments can be used to block activity.

Block unknown or unused attachments by default that should not be transmitted over email as a best practice to prevent some vectors, such as .scr, .exe, .pif, .cpl, etc. Some email scanning devices can open and analyze compressed and encrypted formats, such as zip and rar that may be used to conceal malicious attachments in Obfuscated Files or Information.
Users can be trained to identify social engineering techniques and spearphishing emails.
